title: Introduction to Fractions
subject: math

sections.title: What are Fractions?
sections.content:
A fraction represents a part of a whole. When you divide something into equal parts, each part is a fraction of the whole.

For example:
- If you cut a pizza into 8 equal slices and take 3 slices, you have 3/8 of the pizza
- If you share a chocolate bar with 3 friends equally, each person gets 1/4 of the bar

The number on top is called the **numerator** (the parts you have).
The number on bottom is called the **denominator** (the total equal parts).
sections.doubt_prompt: Do you have any questions about fractions, numerators, or denominators? Ask me anything!
sections.ready_message: Great! Now let's test your understanding with some questions.

questions.question: What do we call the top number in a fraction?
hints: It tells you how many parts you have
It starts with 'n' and is on the 'north' (top) of the fraction

questions.question: If you have 5 equal pieces and take 2, what fraction do you have?
hints: How many pieces did you take?
How many total equal pieces were there?

sections.title: Comparing Fractions
sections.content:
When fractions have the same denominator (bottom number), comparing is easy!

**Rule:** When denominators are the same, the fraction with the larger numerator is bigger.

Examples:
- 3/8 is bigger than 1/8 (because 3 > 1)
- 5/10 is bigger than 2/10 (because 5 > 2)

Think of it like pizza slices - if all slices are the same size, having 3 slices is more than having 1 slice!

questions.question: Which is bigger: 4/7 or 2/7?
hints: The denominators are the same, so look at the numerators

questions.question: If Sarah ate 3/8 of a cake and Tom ate 5/8 of the same cake, who ate more?
hints: Compare the numerators when denominators are the same
